newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Afghan women demonstrate against Taleban.
newsitem.headline: Afghan women demonstrate against Taleban.

text.p: About 400 Afghan women students staged a procession in the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif on Wednesday to show their distaste for curbs on women imposed by the Islamist Taleban militia in Kabul.
Witnesses said the women marched from Mazar-i-Sharif University, now the only university in Afghanistan that women are free to attend, to the city's Ali Hazrat shrine.
Organisers said they wanted to show support for women in Kabul and appeal to the international community for help in protecting women's rights in Afghanistan.

"We are disappointed that the women in Kabul have to stay at home," said one of the organisers, Rahullah Hashim, who works for the U.N. urban renewal agency Habitat. "We want to remind them that we care and that we want peace," she told Reuters.
The Taleban ordered women employees, except health workers, to stay at home and effectively prevented girls from going to school after they seized Kabul on September 27.
Similar restrictions were already in force in other parts of Afghanistan controlled by the radical Sunni Moslem militia.
"Islam allows women to have a life," said Fasyan (one name), an engineer who lectures at Mazar-i-Sharif University. "Women should go to school, not be illiterate. We won't accept this."
She said restrictions on women's right to work were particularly hard on the thousands of Afghan war widows who had no other means to support themselves and their children.
Mazar-i-Sharif is controlled by General Abdul Rashid Dostum, leader of an alliance of anti-Taleban factions. Few strictures are imposed in the name of Islam in the six provinces he holds.
The Taleban, led by militant religious scholars trained in Moslem colleges in Pakistan, have vowed to enforce a purist Islamic order throughout Afghanistan.
